body: If i understand this properly. The FUSE mount currently doesn't support reading from he middle of the file. So for example if i have a mount and it has a 5 GB video file. I play this file with any media player, try to jump to the middle this wont work and is currently not supported?

That is correct but it goes a bit further I believe.  Currently vlc, for example, can't even play a file on the fuse mounts because of lack of seek without even advancing the file.  The way most of these players read from files is via offset and when it tries to do that, it doesn't get data.

Where as if something like this was done, it works because the player now understands its a unseekable stream.
rclone cat "robacd-crypt:/Videos/Movies/Dumbo/Dumbo.mp4" |  vlc -
Interesting... Hope to there is an easy fix for this. I know most cloud drives support seeking from files. acd_cli supports this.

As far as I know all the underlying cloud storage systems support http range requests which could be used to build seeking on. It would be quite a lot of work to add it though (rclone supports lots of cloud storage systems!). 

I'd probably make an Object.OpenRange(start, end) which has would return an io.ReadCloser. This could maybe be built on an Object.OpenWithHttpHeaders which could come in useful for other things... 

Another alternative is to buffer the file to disk and use that to support seeking which would have some advantages but the major disadvantage that seeking to the end would require downloading the whole file.
I am not smart enough to look at the code. But how is it done in https://github.com/yadayada/acd_cli?

issue.title: Enhancement: Optional Caching of upload/downloads to improve stream stability

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
I would like to propose a optional "cache on copy" when using mounts and copying(or cat'ing). 

i.e. Designate a temp directory and when a copy (or stream/seek/cat) occurs cache the file at full (or bandwidth throttled) speed to the temp directory and keep serving the requests for a period of time from that location. Trying to eliminate intermittent problems from the streaming client.

Caching the uploads would allow the size of it to be known in advance and retries to be done which would make it much more reliable. Caching uploads and downloads would make them both seekable. 

The idea here is for applications that would use rclone mounts, you'd want to cache as much data as possible to the temp directory and serve that data to the client when requested.  You'd want to cache _ahead_ of the client as much as possible so that each 'seek' of the client is directed at the local cached copy.

This would require some ability to manage the size of the cache.  This could be done either by time or by 'pressure' on the cache.  i.e. define a max size and when the temp area feels pressure, it would free the oldest items if they were not actively in use.  If there was nothing to free, it would simply not cache and warn the user of the temp size may not be adequate.  We should also consider a configurable max time an item could remain in the cache to prevent very old files from being served to the client.

body:
I would think no matter what we'd need seeking on the http stream.  I do like the buffering but there are also lots of clients that wouldn't have the storage space to buffer a whole file.  (raspi devices for example).

@justusiv I think the point  was that he'd have to make that seeking work across not just acd but all the remotes.  or at least ones that support it (which is the majority).

Have a go with this beta which implements http seeking: http://pub.rclone.org/v1.33-17-g7b80335-fuse-seek%CE%B2/

I can now play and skip around videos with rclone mount.

Note that seeking doesn't work over crypt yet (it will eventually just need a bit more brainpower than I have right now to work out how to do it!).  It does work over all the other remotes though.
Seems to work good.  I've tested it with VLC and it worked great.  I want to test it with movies on xbmc next.  Thanks a lot.  and you are fast!

It worked kind of with xbmc.  It was a bit slow though and the mount was throwing errors.I can get a better debug tomorrow. 

2016/09/10 21:44:28 kitchen/20160908/20160908-115316-1607.avi: ReadFileHandle.Read e
rror: set tcp 10.100.1.195:39305: use of closed network connection
2016/09/10 21:44:30 kitchen/20160908/20160908-115316-1607.avi: ReadFileHandle.Read e
rror: set tcp 10.100.1.195:41263: use of closed network connection
2016/09/10 21:44:41 kitchen/20160908/20160908-115316-1607.avi: ReadFileHandle.Read e
rror: set tcp 10.100.1.195:42346: use of closed network connection
2016/09/10 21:44:54 kitchen/20160908/20160908-115316-1607.avi: ReadFileHandle.Read e
rror: set tcp 10.100.1.195:42386: use of closed network connection
2016/09/10 21:45:13 kitchen/20160908/20160908-115459-1608.avi: ReadFileHandle.Read e
rror: set tcp 10.100.1.195:33035: use of closed network connection

This is with -v.  I can turn on further debugging if that helps.  These are pretty small bitrate files but it is still really slow to play after a seek.  Might just be the latency with acd.  Not sure. but i would have expected the time to initially play the file and the time to resume after a seek would be the same... but it is slower. btw, this test was using mx player over the network rather than xbmc/kodi.

[r.log.gz](https://github.com/ncw/rclone/files/465734/r.log.gz)
Thanks for testing.  Note that seeks will be slow as they have to re-open the connection to the server.  Will examine your log a bit later!

Yes. I did some wall clock timing and the time to initially start the stream is equal or similar to the time to seek to the middle which is what I would expect.  

I did, however, do some benchmarking using acdcli under the same setup.  The rclone mount tool ~15-17 seconds to open the stream and them about the same time to seek.  The acdcli took under a second to open and under a second to seek.  It is interesting because rclone gives my full bandwidth on copies (acdcli gives maybe 2MB/s)...

One more test.  I have a http server pointed to the rclone mount and when I download a file with curl, I get 40k/s speed.  The http server will download in chunks (seek) so it simulates a stream but will download at full speed where a movie stream will only download what it needs to play the stream based on bitrate.  This explains why kodi was stuttering when streaming with a low bitrate avi

Just throwing in my own observations. First i am using the http://pub.rclone.org/v1.33-17-g7b80335-fuse-seek%CE%B2/ I don't have great internet 30/5. I am not able to seek but i am actually not even able play videos from the beginning of the fuse mount. They start but just turns blocky gray and freezes. When i watch traffic while trying i am getting like 10mbit however if i copy a file down from the mount i max my bandwidth at 30mbit.
So yeah big difference between downloading the file and actually playing it live. Am happy to test anything.
Lots to think about thanks for your useful tests. Looks like I probably need to increase some buffering in fuse. Will examine the source if the competition some more!
I will test this but does anyone have some insight? would setting up a share and reading from the share make it more of a linear read for rclone?

Tested. No luck. From my windows box playing a video from the start it would stutter and only transfer 6mbit. copy the file over would max my 30mbit connection.
So much for tricking it :P
I did some testing with speeds on seeking/playing with rclone vs acd_cli with encfs. Are you interested in seeing any of this info? If you are i can wipe up something semi structured.
@justusiv That would be the interesting if it isn't too much bother, thanks.

I'd love to see this working with the crypt storage :-) Keep up the good work!

PS: Kudos on the mount/crypt implementation, best one I've tested so far

I meant to mention this earlier... but i don't think you will like my data.... My connection is to slow to even matter. I can't stream anything with out buffering issues even maxing out my connection.

Any progress on seek using crypt?

@justusiv I've got quite a bit of encrypted media uploaded. I'll try and mount/play the content when I get home to see if I can reproduce the slow speeds that you are experiencing. What are you using to playback the media?
